column4: How can I enable a non-UTF-8 locale in Ubuntu, such as ISO-8859-1?
and depends what you mean by enabling and in which context.
Yeah, I don't want to use it generally, just for a specific application by passing LANG=sv_SE.ISO-8859-1
ahhhh that's easy. Just make sure you got the relevant locale files.

Yeah, that's how I've done it before in Debian, but running dpkg-reconfigure locales doesn't bring up the config program where you can select the locales, it just generates locales that are chosen from somewhere.
there is a difference between choosing which locales are available (as listed by 'locale -a') and which one is active. What's the problem?
Like I said when I run "dpkg-reconfigure locales" it just starts generating the locales, but I want to select a new locale to generate.
but that also allows you to select which locales it generates.
Aha, but how? It just starts generating right away without showing that dialog window I always used to get in Debian.
Try it yourself and you'll see
Aha. Any idea who I should ask about it?
this channel of course :-) Or Google or the Wiki :-).
anyhow have a look at '/etc/locale-gen' and the 'locale-gen' command.
Adding "sv_SE.ISO-8859-1 ISO-8859-1 in the file "/var/lib/locales/supported.d/sv" worked, just for your information.
that is a very odd location.
